title: SEO Definition üîç
ques: What is **SEO** and how does it differ from paid advertising (SEM)?

answer.content:
*   **SEO (Search Engine Optimization):** The practice of optimizing content to rank higher in **organic** (unpaid) search engine results.
*   **Difference:** Paid ads appear instantly but cost money per click. SEO takes time to build but provides "free," sustainable traffic.

explanation: SEO is about understanding what people are searching for and creating content that answers those queries better than anyone else.

title: Title Tags üè∑Ô∏è
ques: The `<title>` tag is considered one of the most important on-page SEO factors. Why? Where does it appear?

answer.content:
It appears as the **clickable headline** in search engine results pages (SERPs). It also appears in the browser tab.
It tells both the search engine and the user exactly what the page is about in one sentence.

explanation: A good title is descriptive, concise (under 60 chars), and includes the main keyword.

title: Meta Description üìù
ques: Does the `<meta name="description">` tag directly affect ranking? What is its primary purpose?

answer.content:
**No**, Google has stated it does not use the description as a direct ranking signal. 
**Purpose:** It acts as the "ad copy" in the search results (the snippet below the link). A compelling description improves the **Click-Through Rate (CTR)**, which *is* a ranking factor.

explanation: Think of the Meta Description as your sales pitch to get the user to click your link instead of a competitor's.

title: URL Structure üîó
ques:
Which URL is better for SEO and why?
1.  `example.com/products/item?id=123`
2.  `example.com/products/blue-denim-jacket`

answer.content:
Option 2 is better.
**Reason:** It is human-readable and contains relevant keywords (`blue`, `denim`, `jacket`). Search engines use URL words to understand page context.

explanation: Clean URLs are user-friendly strings that persist in history and are easier to share.

title: Site Speed as a Ranking Factor ‚ö°
ques: Since 2010 (and more so with Core Web Vitals), Google uses **page speed** as a ranking signal. Why?

answer.content: Google prioritizes User Experience. Users (especially on mobile) bounce immediately if a page is slow. To serve its users the best results, Google penalizes slow sites and boosts fast ones.

explanation: Performance Optimization is SEO. You cannot rank #1 with a 10-second load time.
